[[Boston College Eagles football|Boston College Eagles]] }} The '''[[Miami Hurricanes]] football program''' competes in the [[Atlantic Coast Conference]] of the [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]]'s [[Football Bowl Subdivision|Division I Football Bowl Subdivision]] for the [[University of Miami]]. The program began in 1926 and has won five [[AP Poll|AP national championships]] ([[1983 Miami Hurricanes football team|1983]], [[1987 Miami Hurricanes football team|1987]], [[1989 Miami Hurricanes football team|1989]], [[1991 Miami Hurricanes football team|1991]], [[2001 Miami Hurricanes football team|2001]]).{{cite web|url=http://www6.miami.edu/miami-magazine/spring2007/featurestory5.html|title=Born and Bred|last=Jones Jr.|first=Robert C.|year=2007|work=Miami: The University of Miami Magazine|accessdate=2009-10-17}} Miami is ranked fourth on the list of All-time Associated Press National Poll Championships, behind Notre Dame, Oklahoma and Alabama.{{cite web |url=http://web1.ncaa.org/web_files/stats/football_records/DI/2008/FBS%20compiled.pdf|title=Football Bowl Subdivision Records|work=NCAA|page=85|accessdate=2009-10-16}} Two Hurricanes have won the [[Heisman Trophy]] and six have been inducted to the [[College Football Hall of Fame]]. Miami also holds a number of [[NFL Draft]] records, including most first round selections in a single draft and most consecutive drafts with at least one first round selection.{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2009/04/12/sports/ncaafootball/12miami.html|title=Miami Hurricanes' First-Round N.F.L. Draft Streak Nears a Likely End|last=Battista|first=Judy|date=2009-04-11|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=2009-07-14}} The team is coached by [[Al Golden (American football)|Al Golden]] and plays its home games at [[Sun Life Stadium]] in [[Miami Gardens, Florida]]. ==History== {{For|year-by-year results|List of Miami Hurricanes football seasons}} ===Beginnings (1926â36)=== UM began with just a freshman football team in 1926. Its first game was played on October 23, [[1926 college football season|1926]], a 7â0 win over [[Rollins College]] before 304 fans.{{cite book|title=2007 University of Miami Football Media Guide|year=2007|pages=??|url=http://hurricanesports.cstv.com/sports/m-footbl/spec-rel/07-media-guide.html|accessdate=2009-10-13}} Under the guidance of head coach [[Howard Buck]], the freshman team posted a perfect 8â0 record in its inaugural season. Two of the wins were against the [[University of Havana]],{{cite web|url=http://grfx.cstv.com/photos/schools/mifl/sports/m-footbl/auto_pdf/08-mg-157-196.pdf|title=2008 UM Football Media Guide|page=158|accessdate=2009-11-24}} one on Thanksgiving Day in Miami and one at Havana on Christmas Day. Miami's last home game at of the season featured a first: the first Hurricane football game played on New Year's Day against [[Samford University|Howard]] at Miami's University Stadium.http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=ZUAuAAAAIBAJ&sjid=WNgFAAAAIBAJ&pg=4042,5369512&dq=miami+hurricanes+football&hl=en Around this time, the team adopted the official nickname "Hurricanes," though the exact timing and origin of the name is unclear; some reports suggest it was in reference to the devastating power of the [[1926 Miami hurricane|1926 hurricane]] that postponed the program's first game by a month, and others that it was suggested by a player in response to rumors that university officials wanted to name the team after local [[flora]] or [[fauna]].{{cite web|url=http://hurricanesports.cstv.com/trads/mifl-name.html|title=Team Name and Logo|work=HurricaneSports.com University website|accessdate=2009-10-13}} Varsity competition began in 1927, with Miami beating Rollins 39â3 in its first game and going on to a 3â6â1 record. The team improved to 4â4â1 in [[1928 college football season|1928]], but it was not enough for Buck to keep his job, and he was replaced prior to the [[1929 college football season|1929 season]] with [[J. Burton Rix]], previously head coach at [[Southern Methodist Mustangs football|Southern Methodist]]. Rix's arrival was funded by a group of local businessmen.{{cite web|url=http://hurricanesports.cstv.com/sports/m-footbl/archive/043002aaa.html|title=Material from the book "Hurricane Watch"|first=Jim|last=Martz|accessdate=2009-10-14}} That off-season, the program, which competed as an [[NCAA Division I FBS independent schools|independent]] during its first two years of existence, joined the [[Southern Intercollegiate Athletic Association]] (SIAA). 1929 saw Miami play its first varsity road game (a 14â0 loss at [[Louisiana-Lafayette Ragin' Cajuns football|Southwest Louisiana]]), and Rix led the team to its first winning season, going 3â2. His tenure, however, was short-lived; off-campus financing for the program dried up in the wake of the [[Wall Street Crash of 1929|1929 stock market crash]], and he resigned after one season. [[Ernest E. Brett|Ernest Brett]] replaced Rix, and in [[1930 college football season|1930]], Miami played [[Temple Owls football|Temple]] in its first game outside [[Southern United States|the South]], losing 34â0 to the Owls in [[Atlantic City, New Jersey]]. On October 31, 1930, the Hurricanes played in one of the nation's first night games vs. Bowden College in Miami.http://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&q=cache:vArEOz9DKokJ:grfx.cstv.com/photos/schools/mifl/sports/m-footbl/auto_pdf/fb-09-mg-pdf-7.pdf+burdine+stadium+first+night+game&hl=en&gl=us&pid=bl&srcid=ADGEESgKYaf_MV7ZRmB2STDxGdzBwqExPB2BLxChTrDeO8jjXjzpsa1bl49k1st8Z4nFOmboHIvyYNazOO4oBi-hdOnPBrXOKpmGcsEKfy6sVV-rlCzRmY0SCURvLQFCg21eAU2nnq7I&sig=AHIEtbRdIAjowyHAVDe0XZH5gD6qFAJicA Brett only lasted one year, and [[Thomas McCann|Tom McCann]] became the program's fourth head coach in 1931. Under McCann, the football program experienced its most successful seasons to that point. After a difficult first year, Miami put together a winning [[1932 college football season|record in 1932]] and served as host to the inaugural [[Orange Bowl#Palm Festival|Palm Festival]] (later to be known as the [[Orange Bowl]]), defeating [[Manhattan College]] 7â0 at Moore Park in Miami. A 5â1â2 campaign and another Palm Festival berth followed in [[1933 college football season|1933]], and in [[1934 college football season|1934]], the program played in its first official [[bowl game]], losing to [[Bucknell Bison|Bucknell]] in the first Orange Bowl, 26â0. In 1935, a group of Miami football supporters sought to hire [[Red Grange]] as coach. However, the move was vetoed by President [[Bowman Foster Ashe]], in part because of the $7,500 salary that Grange had requested.{{cite web|url=http://scholar.library.miami.edu/umhistory/DisplaySubjects.php?DisplayPages&subject_id=Athletics¤t_page=1|title=University of Miami Legacy Images|accessdate=2009-11-28}} Instead [[Irl Tubbs]] took over as head coach in 1935, and though Miami compiled an 11â5â2 record in his two seasons, it did not play in a bowl in either year.{{cite web|url=http://grfx.cstv.com/photos/schools/mifl/sports/m-footbl/auto_pdf/08-mg-157-196.pdf|title=2008 UM Football Media Guide|page=165|accessdate=2009-11-24}} ===Jack Harding era (1937â47)=== After [[Irl Tubbs]] resigned following the [[1936 college football season|1936 season]] to become head coach at [[Iowa Hawkeyes football|Iowa]], [[Jack Harding]] was hired to serve as both head football coach and [[athletic director]] at Miami. In 1937, the Hurricanes moved into the brand new [[Miami Orange Bowl|Burdine Municipal Stadium]] (renamed the Orange Bowl in 1959), located west of downtown [[Miami]]. The following year, Miami played archrival [[1938 Florida Gators football team|Florida]] for the first time, defeating the Gators 19â7 at [[Florida Field]], and won the program's first [[Southern Intercollegiate Athletic Association]] title with an 8â2 record. The Hurricanes, though, left the SIAA just three years later, becoming an [[NCAA Division I FBS independent schools|independent]] once again. Harding led the Hurricanes to eight- and seven- win campaigns in 1941 and 1942, respectively, before he was called away by [[World War II]] service. [[Eddie Dunn]], a former star running back at Miami under Harding, stepped into the void and served as head coach during Harding's two-year war service. Though the Hurricanes won five games in Dunn's first season, they faltered in the second, winning just one game against seven losses and a tie. Fortunes changed with Harding's return in 1945, as the Hurricanes went 9â1â1 and returned to the [[Orange Bowl (game)|Orange Bowl]] for the first time since 1934, defeating [[Holy Cross Crusaders football|Holy Cross]] 13â6 in a memorable game.{{cite news|url=http://www.miamiherald.com/multimedia/sports/obspecial/story1.html|title=Plenty of Memories|last=Pope|first=Edwin|date=2007-11-10|work=[[The Miami Herald]]|accessdate=2009-10-13}} With the score tied 6â6 and only seconds remaining, Holy Cross quarterback Gene DeFilippo was intercepted by Miami's Al Hudson at the 11-yard line. Hudson dashed 89 yards the other way for the game-winning touchdown as time expired. Harding's Hurricanes won eight games in 1946, but after the team slipped to 2â7â1 in 1947, he resigned as head coach, but continued as Athletic Director. He hired [[Andy Gustafson]] as the new head coach, closing out a nine-year tenure in which Miami went 54â29â3 and won at least 8 games in four different seasons. ===Andy Gustafson era (1948â63)=== {{Main|1962 Miami Hurricanes football team}} One of [[Andy Gustafson]]'s major innovations at Miami was the "drive series" offense, an [[option offense|option-oriented attack]] from the [[Split-T]] formation that relied on [[zone blocking]] and featured either a [[fullback (American football)|fullback]] fake or carry on every play.{{cite news|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/MAG1069459/1/index.htm|title=Drive at Miami: Coach Andy Gustafson has the system and the men|last=Hickman|first=Herman|date=1955-04-11|work=[[Sports Illustrated]]|accessdate=2009-10-13}}{{cite news|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/MAG1069462/index.htm|title=The Theory Of The Drive Series|last=Hickman|first=Herman|date=1955-04-11|work=[[Sports Illustrated]]|accessdate=2009-10-13}} Under Gustafson's tutelage, Miami produced its first [[College Football All-America Team|All-American]], Al Carapella, in 1950 and went 9â1â1 in [[1951 college football season|1951]], including a 35â13 win in its first-ever game against rival [[Florida State Seminoles football|Florida State]] and a 15â14 loss to [[Clemson Tigers football|Clemson]] in the [[Orange Bowl (game)|Orange Bowl]].{{cite web|url=http://hurricanesports.cstv.com/sports/m-footbl/stats/010204aaa.html|title=Miami Bowl History|work=HurricaneSports.com|accessdate=2009-10-13}} The [[1952 college football season|following season]], Miami won eight games and went to a bowl game in consecutive years for the first time in school history, shutting out Clemson 14â0 in a rematch at the [[Gator Bowl]]. In the middle of the [[1954 college football season|1954 season]], the [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]] imposed two one-year [[NCAA probation|penalties]] against Miami for providing transportation and tryouts to prospective players.{{cite news|url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1356&dat=19561114&id=6SYTAAAAIBAJ&sjid=0QQEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6999,3305992|title=Arbitrary, To Say The Least â Harding|first=Associated Press|date=1956-11-14|work=[[Ocala Star-Banner]]|accessdate=2009-10-13}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} As a result, Gustafson's 1954 squad was ineligible to play in a [[bowl game]], and the 8â1 Hurricanes, whose lone loss came 14â13 at No. 14 [[Auburn Tigers football|Auburn]], finished the season ranked ninth in the [[Coaches' Poll#College football|Coaches' Poll]], the first top ten poll finish in school history. Two years later, an 8â1â1 Miami team, led by team captain and All-American [[Don Bosseler]], was under consideration to play in the [[Sugar Bowl]], but the program's bowl-ban was not due to expire until ten days after the game, rendering it ineligible to participate. The team finished the season ranked sixth in both the [[AP Poll|AP]] and Coaches' Polls. In the later years of Gustafson's tenure, two-time All-America quarterback [[George Mira]] guided the Hurricanes to berths in the [[1961 college football season|1961]] [[Liberty Bowl]] and the [[1962 college football season|1962]] [[Gotham Bowl]], where they lost both games.{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2007/12/20/sports/ncaafootball/20bowls.html|title=Paying Homage to Visions of Bowl Games Gone By|last=Reisler|first=Jim|date=2007-12-20|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=2009-10-13}}{{cite web|url=http://www.mmbolding.com/bowls/Liberty_1961.htm|title=Liberty Bowl 1961: Syracuse 15, Miami 14|last=Sheehan|first=Joseph|date=1961-12-16|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=2009-10-13}} In [[1963 college football season|1963]], the team struggled to a 3â7 record. Nevertheless, Mira, who set many of the school's passing records during his four years at Miami, graced the cover of ''[[Sports Illustrated]]'' and finished fifth in the [[Heisman Trophy]] voting as a senior.{{cite web|url=http://cfn.scout.com/2/598458.html|title=Heisman History...1960 to 1969|date=2008-12-07|work=Scout.com|accessdate=2009-10-13}}{{cite news|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/cover/featured/7838/index.htm|title=Special Issue: College Football|date=1963-09-23|work=[[Sports Illustrated]]|accessdate=2009-10-14}} Following the season, Gustafson decided to step down as head coach and [[Charlie Tate]], an assistant at [[Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets football|Georgia Tech]], was hired to replace him.{{cite news|url=http://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F00E13F63F55127B93C6AB1789D95F478685F9&scp=7&sq=Henry%20King%20Stanford%20Miami&st=cse|title=Georgia Tech Aide Named Miami Coach|work=New York Times|date=December 24, 1963|page=12|accessdate=2010-02-07}} Gustafson has the Hurricane record for most years as head coach (16) and most wins as well (93). ===Charlie Tate era (1964â69)=== {{Main|1966 Miami Hurricanes football team}} {{See also|1966 Liberty Bowl}} [[Charlie Tate]]'s first seasons at Miami were uneventful, with the team posting a 4â5â1 record in [[1964 college football season|1964]] and a reverse 5â4â1 record in [[1965 college football season|1965]]. [[1966 college football season|1966]] brought the arrival of [[defensive end]] [[Ted Hendricks]], the only three-time [[College Football All-America Team|All-American]] in school history, and [[1966 Miami Hurricanes football team|the Hurricanes won eight games]], earning a trip to the [[1966 Liberty Bowl|Liberty Bowl]], where they defeated No. 9 [[Virginia Tech Hokies football|Virginia Tech]], 14â7. In December 1966, the program was [[Racial integration|integrated]] when [[African-American]] [[wide receiver]] Ray Bellamy signed a letter of intent to play football at the university.{{cite book|last=Feldman|first=Bruce|title=Cane Mutiny: How the Miami Hurricanes Overturned the Football Establishment|publisher=[[New American Library]]|location=New York|year=2004|isbn=0-451-21297-5|accessdate=2009-10-13}} Miami returned to bowl play in [[1967 college football season|1967]], dropping the [[Bluebonnet Bowl]] to [[Colorado Buffaloes football|Colorado]], 31â21. The Hurricanes had a 5â5â0 season in 1968 and 4â6â0 in 1969, and Tate resigned as head coach two games into the [[1970 college football season|1970 season]], later citing burn out and fatigue from "fighting the money battle and other battles" as the basis for his decision.{{cite news|url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1320&dat=19880419&id=2DkRAAAAIBAJ&sjid=HeoDAAAAIBAJ&pg=2126,1248021|title=A Hall of Famer recalls the highlights|last=Hairston|first=Jack|date=1988-04-19|work=[[Gainesville Sun]]|accessdate=2009-10-14}} ===Kichefski, Curci, Elliot, and Selmer (1970â76)=== [[Walt Kichefski]], an assistant on Tate's staff, was elevated to interim head coach in the wake of Tate's resignation and coached the team to a 3â8 record in 1970. He was not retained the following season and [[Fran Curci]], a former [[College Football All-America Team|All-American]] quarterback under [[Andy Gustafson]], was chosen as the program's new head coach. Curci's 1971 team improved by a game, but rival [[1971 Florida Gators football team|Florida Gators]] defeated Miami in a game that came to be known as "the Florida Flop.""{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/espn/wire?id=1609982|title=FloridaâMiami rivalry has bitter history|date=2003-09-05|work=[[ESPN.com]]|accessdate=2009-10-15}} With Florida leading 45â8 late in the fourth quarter, the Gator defense allowed Miami to score so that Florida would get the ball back and quarterback [[John Reaves]] would have the opportunity to gain the 15 yards he needed to break the [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]] record for career passing yards.{{cite book|last=Feldman|first=Bruce|title=Cane Mutiny: How the Miami Hurricanes Overturned the Football Establishment|publisher=[[New American Library]]|location=New York|year=2004|page=4|isbn=0-451-21297-5|accessdate=2009-10-13}} [[1972 college football season|1972]] brought another memorable finish for Miami, when the inadvertent gift of a "fifth down" by officials enabled the Hurricanes to edge [[Tulane Green Wave football|Tulane]] in the waning moments of the game for a 24â21 win.{{cite web|url=http://www.tulanegreenwave.com/sports/m-footbl/archive/history.html|title=Tulane Football History|work=TulaneGreenWave.com|accessdate=2009-10-14}}{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/14/sports/view-of-sport-fifth-down-or-not-it-s-over-when-it-s-over.html|title=Fifth Down or Not, It's Over When It's Over|last=Nelson|first=David M.|date=1990-10-14|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=2009-10-14}} Curci left the program at the conclusion of the season and was replaced by [[Pete Elliot]]. Elliot, in turn, lasted two seasons and stepped down in 1975 to become Miami's [[athletic director]]. [[Offensive coordinator]] [[Carl Selmer]] was named the program's fifth head coach in six years.{{cite news|url=http://grfx.cstv.com/photos/schools/mifl/sports/m-footbl/auto_pdf/08-mg-157-196.pdf|title=2008 Football Media Guide|page=159|date=July 28, 2008|accessdate=2009-11-07}} Under Selmer, a trend that started earlier in the decade continued, with home attendance declining every year. After finishing 2â8 in 1975 and 3â8 in 1976, the university fired Selmer, citing concerns about dwindling attendance and the loss of local [[blue chip (sports)|blue-chip recruits]] to other schools. ===Lou Saban era (1977â78)=== [[Image:Lou Saban.jpg|thumb|[[Lou Saban]]]] After a national search, [[Lou Saban]], formerly head coach of the [[NFL]]'s [[Buffalo Bills]], [[Denver Broncos]], and [[New England Patriots|Boston Patriots]], was hired on December 27, 1976, as head coach. Miami only won three games in [[1977 college football season|1977]], but Saban was able to put together a well-regarded recruiting class that included future [[Pro Football Hall of Fame]] quarterback [[Jim Kelly]] of [[East Brady, Pennsylvania]]. Kelly had been recruited by [[Penn State Nittany Lions football|Penn State]] as a [[linebacker]] and agreed to come to Miami after Saban promised him he would play quarterback. Among the other 30 signees in Saban's first recruiting class were 11 future NFL players. The Hurricanes improved by three games in Saban's second season and [[Ottis Anderson]] emerged as an NFL talent. Anderson became the first Miami running back to rush for 1,000 yards in a season and led the team in rushing for three straight seasons from 1977 through 1979. Anderson set numerous school rushing records and {{as of|2009|lc=on}} remains Miami's career rushing leader. After just two seasons as head coach, Saban resigned in the wake of a controversy concerning football players throwing a Jewish man into [[Lake Osceola]], an on campus lake.{{cite book|last=Feldman|first=Bruce|title=Cane Mutiny: How the Miami Hurricanes Overturned the Football Establishment|publisher=[[New American Library]]|location=New York|year=2004|pages=17â18|isbn=0-451-21297-5|accessdate=2009-10-13}} He left after the [[1978 college football season|1978 season]] to take the head coaching position at [[Army Black Knights football|Army]].{{cite news|url=http://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F60D16F83B5D12728DDDAC0894D9405B898BF1D3&scp=13&sq=%22University%20of%20Miami%22&st=cse|title=Army Hires Saban of Miami as 28th Football Coach; 9 Jobs in 29 Years 'Longer Than Homer's' Boston Patriots' Coach|first=Gordon|last=White|date=January 5, 1979|page=A13|accessdate=2010-02-05 | work=The New York Times}} Saban's departure, the constant coaching upheaval Miami experienced during the decade, and assorted fiscal problems sparked the university's Board of Trustees to hold a vote on whether to drop the football program down to the [[Division I-AA]] level or eliminate it altogether.{{cite book|last=Feldman|first=Bruce|title=Cane Mutiny: How the Miami Hurricanes Overturned the Football Establishment|publisher=[[New American Library]]|location=New York|year=2004|page=18|isbn=0-451-21297-5|accessdate=2009-10-13}} University executive vice president Dr. John Green was able to convince the board to give [[Division I-A]] football another shot and hired the pipe-smoking [[Howard Schnellenberger]], [[offensive coordinator]] for the NFL's [[Miami Dolphins]], to succeed Saban. ===Howard Schnellenberger era (1979â83)=== {{Main|1980 Miami Hurricanes football team|1981 Miami Hurricanes football team|1982 Miami Hurricanes football team|1983 Miami Hurricanes football team}} {{See also|1981 Peach Bowl (January)}} At the outset of his tenure, [[Howard Schnellenberger]] announced to his staff and players his intention to win a [[NCAA Division I FBS National Football Championship|national championship]] within five years.{{cite book|last=Feldman|first=Bruce|title=Cane Mutiny: How the Miami Hurricanes Overturned the Football Establishment|publisher=[[New American Library]]|location=New York|year=2004|page=19|isbn=0-451-21297-5|accessdate=2009-10-13}} His five-year plan had two main priorities: installing a [[Pro Style|pro-style]] passing offense and upgrading the talent level on the roster through a new recruiting strategy aimed at retaining the best local talent. To help with the offense, Schnellenberger hired former [[Indianapolis Colts|Baltimore Colts]] quarterback [[Earl Morrall]] as a volunteer quarterbacks coach. On the recruiting front, he spoke of mining the "State of Miami," which entailed fencing off the fertile [[South Florida]] recruiting base from other programs and [[cherry-picking]] the rest of the nation for a few choice recruits.{{cite book|last=Feldman|first=Bruce|title=Cane Mutiny: How the Miami Hurricanes Overturned the Football Establishment|publisher=[[New American Library]]|location=New York|year=2004|page=24|isbn=0-451-21297-5|accessdate=2009-10-13}} Schnellenberger also sought to exploit the freedom provided by Miami's [[NCAA Division I FBS independent schools|independent]] schedule to gain "intersectional exposure" and make the program "national."{{cite book|last=Feldman|first=Bruce|title=Cane Mutiny: How the Miami Hurricanes Overturned the Football Establishment|publisher=[[New American Library]]|location=New York|year=2004|page=22|isbn=0-451-21297-5|accessdate=2009-10-13}} On the field, Miami went 5â6 in Schnellenberger's debut season, which was highlighted by a 26â10 upset win at No. 16 [[Penn State Nittany Lions|Penn State]] in which [[Redshirt (college sports)|redshirt]] freshman [[Jim Kelly]] threw for 280 yards and three touchdowns in his first career start as Miami's quarterback.{{cite book|last=Feldman|first=Bruce|title=Cane Mutiny: How the Miami Hurricanes Overturned the Football Establishment|publisher=[[New American Library]]|location=New York|year=2004|page=31|isbn=0-451-21297-5|accessdate=2009-10-13}} Schnellenberger set a bowl berth as the goal of the [[1980 Miami Hurricanes football team|1980 campaign]] and the team made good on its head coach's expectations, winning nine games and earning a trip to the [[Peach Bowl]], where the Hurricanes defeated [[Virginia Tech Hokies football|Virginia Tech]] 20â10. The bowl berth was Miami's first since 1967 and the team finished the season ranked eighteenth in both the [[AP Poll|AP]] and [[Coaches' Poll|Coaches']] Polls. Miami continued to improve in [[1981 NCAA Division I-A football season|1981]], going 9â2 and defeating then-No. 1 Penn State 17â14 in a late-October game at the [[Miami Orange Bowl|Orange Bowl]]. In the season's final game, the Hurricanes topped rival [[1981 Notre Dame Fighting Irish football team|Notre Dame]] for the first time since 1960, 37â15, finishing the season eighth in the AP Poll. The [[1982 Miami Hurricanes football team|following season]], the team finished with four losses following Kelly's shoulder injury. Entering the [[1983 NCAA Division I-A football season|1983 season]]âthe fifth of Schnellenberger's tenureâthe program had to find a replacement for the recently-graduated Kelly. Ultimately, Schnellenberger chose [[Bernie Kosar]] as the team's starting quarterback over fellow redshirt freshman [[Vinny Testaverde]]. The [[1983 Miami Hurricanes football team|1983 Miami Hurricanes]] started the season unranked and lost 28â3 at [[1983 Florida Gators football team|Florida]] in their first game, though Kosar tied [[George Mira]]'s single-game school record of 25 pass completions. The Hurricanes rallied by winning their next 10 games, including a 20â0 early-season shutout of [[1983 Notre Dame Fighting Irish football team|Notre Dame]], and earned a berth to the [[1984 Orange Bowl]] to play the undefeated, top-ranked [[1983 Nebraska Cornhuskers football team|Nebraska]] team that had both [[Mike Rozier]] and [[Turner Gill]]. The Orange Bowl-berth was Miami's first since 1951, but the program's first national championship remained a long shot, as the Hurricanes entered the game ranked fifth. Miami got much needed help early on New Year's Day when second-ranked [[Texas Longhorns football|Texas]], the nation's other undefeated team, lost in the [[1984 Cotton Bowl Classic|Cotton Bowl Classic]] and fourth-ranked [[Illinois Fighting Illini football|Illinois]] lost in the [[1984 Rose Bowl|Rose Bowl]].{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/abcsports/bcs/orange/s/1984.html|title=1984 â Miami 31, Nebraska 30|last=O'Sullivan|first=Dan|date=2002-12-13|work=ABC Sports Online|accessdate=2009-10-14}} Behind Kosar's passing, Miami jumped out to a 17â0 lead, but Nebraska battled back and cut Miami's lead to 31â24 in the fourth quarter. With 48 seconds remaining, Nebraska scored a touchdown to make it 31â30 and, being the number one-ranked team in the nation, needed only to kick the extra point to tie the game and put itself in position to win the national championship. Nebraska head coach [[Tom Osborne]] elected to go for the win and attempt a two-point conversion instead. On the ensuing play, Miami [[Safety (American football position)|safety]] Ken Calhoun tipped away Gill's pass to receiver Jeff Smith in the end zone, saving the game and winning Miami the national championship when it leap-frogged No. 3 [[1983 Auburn Tigers football team|Auburn]] to finish first in the final polls. Although Schnellenberger had made good on his five-year plan to win a national championship, he left after the season to accept a head coaching position in the [[USFL]]. Two weeks later, athletic director [[Sam Jankovich]] hired [[Jimmy Johnson (American football coach)|Jimmy Johnson]] from [[Oklahoma State Cowboys football|Oklahoma State]] to fill the vacancy.{{cite web|url=http://grfx.cstv.com/photos/schools/mifl/sports/m-footbl/auto_pdf/08-mg-157-196.pdf|title=2008 UM Football Media Guide|page=160|accessdate=2009-11-20|date=July 28, 2008}} ===Jimmy Johnson era (1984â88)=== {{Main|1987 Miami Hurricanes football team|1988 Miami Hurricanes football team}} {{See also|1984 Orange Bowl|Hail Flutie|1985 Fiesta Bowl|1986 Sugar Bowl|1987 Fiesta Bowl|1988 Notre Dame vs. Miami football game|1988 Orange Bowl}} [[File:Miami Orange Bowl.jpg|thumb|right|275px|The [[Miami Orange Bowl]], the Hurricanes' home field until its 2008 demolition]] One of [[Jimmy Johnson (American football coach)|Jimmy Johnson]]'s immediate priorities upon taking over as Miami head coach was to switch to a 4â3 defense. Johnson wanted to implement the change for his first season, but lacking the time, personnel, and staff, he decided to postpone the switch and kept Schnellenberger's 5â2 defensive package for the 1984 season.{{cite book|last=Feldman|first=Bruce|title=Cane Mutiny: How the Miami Hurricanes Overturned the Football Establishment|publisher=[[New American Library]]|location=New York|year=2004|page=55|isbn=0-451-21297-5|accessdate=2009-10-13}} The team struggled to an 8â5 record in Johnson's first season, losing a number of noteworthy games. In the next-to-last game of the regular season, the No. 6 Hurricanes squandered a 31â0 halftime lead against [[1984 Maryland Terrapins football team|Maryland]] and lost 42â40 in what was then the biggest comeback in NCAA football history.{{cite web|url=http://www.forbes.com/2009/09/11/biggest-comeback-wins-lifestyle-sports-comebacks.html|title=Sports' Greatest Comeback Wins|last=Burke|first=Monte|date=2009-09-11|work=[[Forbes]].com|accessdate=2009-10-14}} The following week, Miami lost 47â45 when [[1984 Boston College Eagles football team|Boston College]]'s [[Doug Flutie]] connected with [[Gerard Phelan]] for a 48-yard [[Hail Mary pass|Hail Mary]] touchdown on the final play in what has been called the [[Hail Flutie]] game.{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/espn/classic/bio/news/story?page=Flutie_Doug|title=Hail Flutie|last=Schwartz|first=Kris|date=2006-05-18|work=[[ESPN.com]]|accessdate=2009-10-14}} The Hurricanes ended the season on a three-game losing streak by dropping the [[1985 Fiesta Bowl]] to [[1984 UCLA Bruins football team|UCLA]], 39â37, in a game that featured six lead changes.{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/abcsports/bcs/fiesta/s/1985.html|title=1985 â UCLA 39, Miami 37|last=Burchette|first=Jordan|work=ABCSports.com|accessdate=2009-10-14}} During the off-season, Johnson made a number of coaching changes, facilitating the switch to the 4â3 defense, and junior [[Vinny Testaverde]] succeeded early-graduate [[Bernie Kosar]] at quarterback. The 1985 Hurricanes opened the season with a loss at [[1985 Florida Gators football team|Florida]] before winning their next four games, including a 38â0 win over [[Cincinnati Bearcats football|Cincinnati]] that began a then NCAA-record 58 game home winning streak, heading into a matchup at No. 3 [[1985 Oklahoma Sooners football team|Oklahoma]]. Facing the nation's top-rated defense, Testaverde amassed 270 yards passing and threw touchdowns to [[Michael Irvin]] and [[Brian Blades]], while also running for an additional score, in a 27â14 win over the Sooners.{{cite web|url=http://www.sportingnews.com/college-football/article/2007-09-05/its-been-2-decades-and-miami-oklahoma-matchups-still-classic|title=It's been 2 decades, and MiamiâOklahoma matchups still classic|last=Associated Press|date=2007-09-05|work=[[Sporting News|Sporting News.com]]|accessdate=2009-10-14}} The Hurricanes ascended to number two in the rankings following a 58â7 victory over [[1985 Notre Dame Fighting Irish football team|Notre Dame]] in the final game of the regular season, earning a trip to the [[1986 Sugar Bowl|Sugar Bowl]] to play the No. 8 [[1985 Tennessee Volunteers football team|Tennessee Volunteers]]. With No. 1 [[1985 Penn State Nittany Lions football team|Penn State]] losing to Oklahoma in the [[Orange Bowl]], Miami was in position to capture its second [[NCAA Division I FBS National Football Championship|national championship]], but those hopes were dashed with a lopsided 35â7 loss to Tennessee.{{cite web|url=http://allstatesugarbowl.org/site106.php|title=52nd Annual Sugar Bowl Classic ~ January 1, 1986|work=AllStateSugarBowl.org|accessdate=2009-10-14}} Miami opened [[1986 Miami Hurricanes football team|its 1986 season]] as the third-ranked team in the country and climbed to number two after winning its first three games, setting up a No. 1 vs. No. 2 showdown at the Orange Bowl against top-ranked and defending national champion [[1986 Oklahoma Sooners football team|Oklahoma]]. After much pre-game [[trash-talk]] between Oklahoma's [[Brian Bosworth]] and Miami's [[Melvin Bratton]] and [[Alonzo Highsmith]], Testaverde tossed four touchdown passes in a 28â16 win. Testaverde's performance led Oklahoma head coach [[Barry Switzer]] to remark that he had "never seen a better quarterback" in his 21 years with the Sooners, and at the conclusion of the regular season, Testaverde was awarded the [[Heisman Trophy]] with the fifth largest margin of victory in the voting's history.{{cite web|url=http://www.heisman.com/winners/v-testaverde86.php|title=1986 â 52nd Award â Vinny Testaverde|work=Heisman.com|accessdate=2009-10-14}} The Hurricanes, having seized the number one ranking with the win over Oklahoma, finished the regular season at 11â0, outscoring their opponents 420â136, and accepted a bid to the [[1987 Fiesta Bowl]] to play No. 2 [[1986 Penn State Nittany Lions football team|Penn State]].{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/espn/eticket/story?page=fiesta87|title=The Night College Football Went to Hell|last=Weinreb|first=Michael|work=[[ESPN.com]]|accessdate=2009-10-14}}{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/abcsports/bcs/fiesta/s/1987.html|title=1987 â Penn State 14, Miami 10|last=O'Sullivan|first=Dan|date=2002-12-13|work=ABCSports.com|accessdate=2009-10-14}} There, the team's "outlaw" image grew when players arrived in Arizona clad in [[battledress|fatigues]] and [[Jerome Brown]] staged a walkout of a pre-game steak fry attended by both teams. Before an estimated television audience of seventy million people, Penn State upset the heavily-favored Hurricanes 14â10 to win the national championship, forcing seven turnovers, including Pete Giftopoulus' game-sealing interception of Testaverde in the end zone in the game's final seconds.{{cite web|url=http://www.fiestabowl.org/index.php/tostitos/history_display/16th_annual_fiesta_bowl/|title=16th Annual Fiesta Bowl|work=FiestaBowl.org|accessdate=2009-10-14}} Led by [[Michael Irvin]] and new quarterback [[Steve Walsh (American football)|Steve Walsh]], the [[1987 Miami Hurricanes football team|1987 Miami Hurricanes]] won the school's second national championship and completed its first undefeated varsity season. The season was highlighted by one of the most memorable games in the history of the [[Miami â Florida State rivalry]]. Trailing No. 4 [[Florida State Seminoles football|Florida State]] 19â3 in the third quarter at [[Doak Campbell Stadium]], the Hurricanes rallied to take a 26â19 lead late in the fourth quarter on a 73-yard touchdown pass from Walsh to Irvin. Florida State responded with a touchdown in the final minute, but Seminoles head coach [[Bobby Bowden]] opted to go for two points and the win rather than kick the extra-point for a tie, and Miami's Bubba McDowell broke up the conversion pass in the end zone to preserve the 26â25 victory. More than 60 players on the combined rosters for the game went on to play in the [[NFL]].{{cite web|url=http://www.sportingnews.com/college-football/article/2007-10-19/talent-filled-1987-miami-florida-state-game-now-distant-past|title=Talent-filled 1987 MiamiâFlorida State game now distant past|date=2007-10-19|work=[[Sporting News|Sporting News.com]]|accessdate=2009-10-14}} The 12â0 campaign was capped by a 20â14 win over the then-No. 1 [[Oklahoma Sooners football|Oklahoma Sooners]] in an [[1988 Orange Bowl|Orange Bowl]] billed as "The Game of the Century." The win was Miami's third over Oklahoma in the last three seasons, accounting for Oklahoma's only losses during that time period. The Hurricanes had a then-school record 12 players from the 1987 team selected in the [[1988 NFL Draft|following spring's NFL Draft]],, including Irvin and [[Bennie Blades]], but with Walsh returning in [[1988 NCAA Division I-A football season|1988]], the team gained the number one ranking with a season-opening 31â0 shutout of then-No. 1 Florida State at the Orange Bowl. The program was widely criticized for its conduct, with [[Will McDonough]] of the ''[[Boston Globe]]'' likening the Cotton Bowl Classic display to a "wilding" and [[Bill Walsh (American football coach)|Bill Walsh]] calling it "the most disgusting thing [he'd] ever seen in college sports." After the season, the [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]] responded with the so-called "Miami Rule", which made it a 15-yard penalty to engage in excessive celebration or flagrant taunting.{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1991-09-05/sports/sp-2372_1_college-football|title=Upon Further Review, Coach Says Referee Blew the Call|last=Wojciechowski|first=Gene|date=1991-09-05|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|accessdate=2009-10-14}} Also during the off-season, Miami ended its 48-year status as an [[NCAA Division I FBS independent schools|independent]] and joined the [[Big East Conference]]. The [[1991 Miami Hurricanes football team|1991 Hurricanes]] captured the program's fourth national championship in nine years behind quarterback [[Gino Torretta]] and a linebacking corps that featured [[Jessie Armstead]] and [[Micheal Barrow]]. Meanwhile, Torretta became the second Hurricane to win the [[Heisman Trophy]], throwing for 19 touchdowns and 3,060 yards on the season and setting 11 school passing records during his career.{{cite web|url=http://www.heisman.com/winners/g-torretta92.php|title=1992 â 57th Award â Gino Torretta|work=Heisman.com|accessdate=2009-10-14}} Miami earned a trip to the [[1993 Sugar Bowl]], where the top-ranked Hurricanes were denied a repeat national championship by No. 2 [[1992 Alabama Crimson Tide football team|Alabama]], 34â13.{{cite web|url=http://allstatesugarbowl.org/site99.php|title=59th Annual Sugar Bowl Classic ~ January 1, 1993|work=AllStateSugarBowl.org|accessdate=2009-10-14}}{{cite news|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/MAG1137538/index.htm|title=The End of the Run|last=Murphy|first=Austin|date=1993-01-11|work=[[Sports Illustrated]]|accessdate=2009-10-14}} The Sugar Bowl loss ended the program's 29-game winning streak, which dated to 1990. The following two seasons yielded less success. In [[1993 NCAA Division I-A football season|1993]], [[1993 Miami Hurricanes football team|Miami lost three games]] in a season for the first time since 1984, failed to win the Big East for the first time since joining in 1991, and was shut out in the [[1994 Fiesta Bowl|Fiesta Bowl]] by [[1993 Arizona Wildcats football team|Arizona]], leading some{{Who|date=August 2010}} to wonder whether the program was in decline.{{cite news|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/MAG1005096/index.htm|title=Hurricane Warning|last=Price|first=S.L.|date=1994-04-14|work=[[Sports Illustrated]]|accessdate=2009-10-14}} In [[1994 NCAA Division I-A football season|1994]], Miami defeated [[Georgia Southern Eagles football|Georgia Southern]] in the season opener for its 58th consecutive home win, setting an NCAA record; the streak, which began in 1985, was snapped two weeks later when [[Washington Huskies football|Washington]] defeated the Hurricanes 38â20 at the [[Miami Orange Bowl|Orange Bowl]].{{cite news|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/MAG1005749/index.htm|title=Dog Day Afternoon|last=Price|first=S.L.|date=1994-10-03|work=[[Sports Illustrated]]|accessdate=2009-10-14}} Led by [[College Football All-America Team|All-American]] defensive tackle [[Warren Sapp]] and sophomore linebacker [[Ray Lewis (American football)|Ray Lewis]], the team rebounded to earn a berth in the [[1995 Orange Bowl]], where No. 1 [[1994 Nebraska Cornhuskers football team|Nebraska]] outscored Miami 15â0 in the final quarter to win the game, 24â17, and the national championship.{{cite book|last=Feldman|first=Bruce|title=Cane Mutiny: How the Miami Hurricanes Overturned the Football Establishment|publisher=[[New American Library]]|location=New York|year=2004|isbn=0-451-21297-5|accessdate=2009-10-13|page=145}} With the threat of NCAA sanctions hovering over the program for a variety of infractions, Erickson stepped down after the 1994 season to become head coach of the NFL's [[Seattle Seahawks]]. Erickson departed Miami with a 63â9 record over six seasons and the highest winning percentage (.875) and most national championships (2) of any coach in school history. ===Butch Davis era (1995â2000)=== {{See also|1995 Orange Bowl}} [[Image:Butch David 70723.jpg|thumb|[[Butch Davis]]]] Several early candidates to replace [[Dennis Erickson]], including former UM defensive coordinator and 1994 ''Sports Illustrated'' Coach of the Year [[Sonny Lubick]], withdrew from consideration. Eventually, Miami settled on former Hurricanes assistant and [[Dallas Cowboys]] defensive coordinator [[Butch Davis]]. The Hurricanes finished Davis' first season with a record of 8â3, which may have drawn a bowl invitation. However, on December 20, 1995 the NCAA announced that Miami would be subject to severe sanctions for numerous infractions within the athletic department. The Hurricanes were forced to sit out postseason play for the 1995 season and docked 31 scholarships from 1996 to 1998. Miami had actually self-reported the violations in 1991. However, when the Department of Education got word that school officials helped athletes fraudulently obtain [[Pell Grant]]s, it asked Miami to stop its own investigation while it conducted its own. Ultimately, 60 athletes were implicated, but all of them avoided criminal charges after being sent through a pretrial diversion program.Holiday, Pete. [http://www.aolnews.com/2007/07/23/footballs-dirtiest-programs-10-miami Football's Dirtiest Programs: #10, Miami]. [[FanHouse]], 2007-07-23. In 1994, Tony Russell, a former UM academic advisor, pleaded guilty to helping more than 80 student athletes, 57 of whom were football players, falsify Pell Grant applications in exchange for kickbacks from the players themselves. The scandal dated all the way back to 1989 and secured more than $220,000 in federal grant money. Federal officials later said that Russell had engineered "perhaps the largest centralized fraud ... ever committed" in the history of the Pell Grant program.{{cite news | title=Why the University of Miami should drop football | accessdate=2006-11-11 | url=http://vault.sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/MAG1006688/index.htm | publisher=CNNSI.com | date=1995-06-12}}{{cite book|last=Feldman|first=Bruce|title=Cane Mutiny: How the Miami Hurricanes Overturned the Football Establishment|publisher=[[New American Library]]|location=New York|year=2004|isbn=0-451-21297-5|accessdate=2009-10-13|pages=131â33, 144, 156â57, 166}} In late 1995, the NCAA concluded that, in addition to the fraudulent Pell Grants facilitated by Russell, the university had also provided or allowed over $400,000 worth of other, improper payments to Miami football players. The NCAA also found that the university had failed to wholly implement its drug testing program, and permitted three football student-athletes to compete without being subject to the required disciplinary measures specified in the policy. Finally, the [[NCAA]] concluded, the university had lost institutional control over the football program.{{cite web | title=1995 Public Infraction Report | accessdate=2006-11-11 | url=https://goomer.ncaa.org/wdbctx/LSDBi/LSDBi.MajorInfPackage.ProcessMultipleBylaws?p_Multiple=0&p_PK=63&p_Button=View+Public+Report&p_TextTerms=ThisIsADummyPhraseThatWillNotBeDuplicated&p_TextTerms2=ThisIsADummyPhraseThatWillNotBeDuplicated&p_Division=1 | publisher=NCAA.org }} Miami docked itself seven scholarships as part of a self-imposed sanction in 1995, and the [[NCAA]] took away another 24 scholarships over the next two years. As a result of the scandal, ''[[Sports Illustrated]]'''s [[Alexander Wolff]] wrote a cover story that Miami should at least temporarily shut down its football program. Further, On June 21, 1996, Miami football players broke into the apartment of the captain of Miami's track team and struck him repeatedly. In response, Davis suspended three key players for the coming 1996 season. Davis also suspended two other players who were involved in separate violent incidents.{{cite news|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/MAG1008584/1/index.htm|title=Though Love: Coach Butch Davis aims to save Miami football no matter how many players he has to suspend|first=William |last=Nack|date=August 19, 1996|accessdate=2009-10-20|work=Sports Illustrated}} The imposition of scholarship reductions led to a long and sometimes painful rebuilding period for the Hurricanes. The low point for Miami came in 1997 when they posted a 5â6 record, the first losing season since Howard Schnellenberger's first year in 1979. The 1997 season saw the Hurricanes suffer one of the program's most humiliating losses, a 47â0 beating at the hands of in-state rival [[1997 Florida State Seminoles football team|Florida State]].{{cite news|url=http://www.theacc.com/sports/m-footbl/spec-rel/100801aau.html|title=MiamiâFlorida State Rivalry Back to Life|last=Long|first=Mark|date=2001-10-08|work=TheACC.com|agency=Associated Press|accessdate=2009-10-12}}{{cite news|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/MAG1011123/index.htm|title=Blown-out Hurricanes|last=Maisel|first=Ivan|date=1997-10-13|work=[[Sports Illustrated]]|accessdate=2009-10-12}} The Hurricanes began to reassert themselves in 1998. In late September, Miami was forced to postpone their game with [[UCLA Bruins Football|UCLA]] due to [[Hurricane Georges]]. The game was rescheduled for December 5 and for the #2-ranked Bruins, a trip to the National Championship game was at stake. The Hurricanes rebounded from a 66â13 "caning" at the hands of Syracuse and Donovan McNabb to put up over 600 yards of total offense against UCLA en route to a stunning 49â45 victory for the Hurricanes. The following season carried high hopes and expectations for the Hurricanes. They opened the year with a 23â12 win over [[1999 Ohio State Buckeyes football team|Ohio State]] in [[East Rutherford, New Jersey|East Rutherford]]. Early success, however, was tempered by tough losses to [[1999 Penn State Nittany Lions football team|Penn State]] and [[1999 Florida State Seminoles football team|Florida State]] during a three game losing streak. The Hurricanes rebounded to win their last 4 games including a 28â13 win over [[Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets football|Georgia Tech]] in the [[Gator Bowl]]. In 2000, Miami was shut out of the [[Bowl Championship Series|BCS]] National Championship Game. Despite beating [[2000 Florida State Seminoles football team|Florida State]] head-to-head and being ranked higher in both human polls, it was the Seminoles that were chosen to challenge the [[2000 Oklahoma Sooners football team|Oklahoma Sooners]] for the national championship. The Seminoles were also chosen over [[2000 Washington Huskies football team|Washington]], who also had one loss and who had handed Miami its only loss early in the season. Washington had been ranked third or fourth in the human polls, behind Miami. The Hurricanes went into the [[2001 Sugar Bowl|2001 Nokia Sugar Bowl]] as the Big East champions and defeated [[2000 Florida Gators football team|Florida]] 37â20. ===Larry Coker era (2001â2006)=== {{Main|2001 Miami Hurricanes football team|2002 Miami Hurricanes football team|2004 Miami Hurricanes football team|2005 Miami Hurricanes football team|2006 Miami Hurricanes football team}} {{See also|2001 Sugar Bowl|2002 Rose Bowl|2003 Fiesta Bowl|2004 Orange Bowl|2004 Peach Bowl (December)|2005 Peach Bowl|2006 MPC Computers Bowl}} On January 29, 2001, [[Butch Davis]] left Miami to become head coach of the [[Cleveland Browns]]. Dee promoted offensive coordinator [[Larry Coker]] to be head coach.{{cite book|last=Feldman|first=Bruce|title=Cane Mutiny: How the Miami Hurricanes Overturned the Football Establishment|publisher=[[New American Library]]|location=New York|year=2004|page=178|isbn=0451212975|accessdate=2009-10-12}} Miami started the season with a 33â7, televised win over [[2001 Penn State Nittany Lions football team|Penn State]] in [[Beaver Stadium]]. Miami followed up the victory with wins over [[Rutgers Scarlet Knights football|Rutgers]], [[Pittsburgh Panthers football|Pittsburgh]], and [[Troy State University|Troy State]]. After building up a 4â0 record, the Hurricanes defeated [[2001 Florida State Seminoles football team|Florida State]] in [[Doak Campbell Stadium]], 49â27, ending the Seminoles' 54-game home unbeaten streak and 37-game home winning streak. The Hurricanes then defeated [[2001 West Virginia Mountaineers football team|West Virginia]], 45â3, and [[Temple University|Temple]], 38â0, before heading to [[Chestnut Hill, MA|Chestnut Hill]] to take on [[Boston College Eagles football|Boston College]]. In the final minute of the fourth quarter, with Miami clinging to a 12â7 lead, Boston College quarterback [[Brian St. Pierre]] led the Eagles from their own 30-yard line all the way down to the Hurricanes' 9. With BC on the verge of a momentous upset, St. Pierre attempted a pass to receiver Ryan Read at the Miami 2-yard line. However, the ball deflected off the leg of Miami cornerback [[Mike Rumph]], landing in the hands of defensive end Matt Walters. Walters ran ten yards with the ball before teammate [[Ed Reed]] grabbed the ball out of his hands at around the Miami 20-yard line and raced the remaining 80-yards for a touchdown, resulting in a 18â7 Miami victory. After surviving the scare from Boston College, Miami shutout #14 [[Syracuse Orange football|Syracuse]], 59â0, and defeated #12 [[Washington Huskies football|Washington]], 65â7 in the Orange Bowl. The combined 124â7 score set what the ''Orlando Sentinel'' described as an NCAA-record for the largest margin of victory over consecutive ranked opponents.{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/columns/story?columnist=schlabach_mark&id=3406050|title=2001 Hurricanes cream of BCS champions crop|last=Schlabach|first=Mark|date=2008-05-21|work=[[ESPN.com]]|accessdate=2009-10-17}}{{cite web|url=http://blogs.orlandosentinel.com/sports_college_uf/2009/07/team-of-the-decade-the-2001-miami-hurricanes.html|title=Team of the decade: The 2001 Miami Hurricanes|last=Adelson|first=Andrea|date=2009-07-02|work=[[Orlando Sentinel]]|accessdate=2009-10-17}} The final hurdle to the [[2002 Rose Bowl]] [[BCS National Championship Game]] was at [[Virginia Tech Hokies football|Virginia Tech]]. Miami led Virginia Tech 20â3 at halftime. Virginia Tech added a couple of late touchdowns, attempting two-point conversions on each. The first conversion was successful, pulling them to 26â18, but receiver Ernest Wilford dropped a pass from quarterback Grant Noel in the endzone for the second conversion. Reed's late interception in the 4th quarter sealed the win for the Hurricanes. Miami's 26â24 victory earned the top-ranked Hurricanes an invitation to the Rose Bowl to take on BCS #2 [[2001 Nebraska Cornhuskers football team|Nebraska]] for the national championship. In the Rose Bowl, the Hurricanes took a 34â0 halftime lead and cruised to a 37â14 win over the Huskers to capture their fifth national championship and put the finishing touches on a perfect 12â0 season. The Miami defense shut down [[Heisman Trophy|Heisman]] winner [[Eric Crouch]] and the vaunted Huskers offense, holding Nebraska 200 yards below its season average. [[Ken Dorsey]] and [[Andre Johnson]] were named [[Rose Bowl (game)|Rose Bowl]] co-Most Valuable Players.{{cite web | accessdate=2007-07-24 | url=http://hurricanesports.cstv.com/sports/m-footbl/archive/043002aaf.html | title=Character, Class And Poise = Championship | author= | date=2007-07-24 | publisher=Hurricanesports.com}} Six Hurricane players earned All-American status and six players were finalists for national awards, including [[Maxwell Award]] winner, [[Ken Dorsey]], and [[Outland Trophy]] winner, [[Bryant McKinnie]]. Dorsey was also a [[Heisman Trophy]] finalist, finishing third. The [[2001 Miami Hurricanes football team|2001 Miami Hurricanes]] are considered by some experts and historians as one of the greatest teams in college football history.{{cite web | accessdate=2007-07-24 | url=http://sports.espn.go.com/chat/sportsnation/story?page=uschistory01miami | title=USC's Place In History: 2001 Miami | author= | date=2007-07-24 | publisher=ESPN.com}} {{Dead link|date=November 2009}} Miami started the 2002 season as the defending national champion and the #1 ranked team in the country. Behind a high-powered offense led by senior quarterback [[Ken Dorsey]], new starting running back [[Willis McGahee]], and a stout defense anchored by [[Jonathan Vilma]], the Hurricanes completed their regular season schedule undefeated. The season was highlighted by a 41â16 win over rival [[2002 Florida Gators football team|Florida]] at [[Ben Hill Griffin Stadium]], the first regular season meeting between the rivals since 1987. The Hurricanes' toughest test was an October clash against rival [[Florida State Seminoles football|Florida State]] at the [[Miami Orange Bowl|Orange Bowl]]. Miami overcame a 13-point second half deficit to defeat the Seminoles, 28â27. The game was clinched when [[2002 Florida State Seminoles football team|Florida State]] kicker [[Xavier Beitia]] missed a 43-yard field goal, wide left, as time expired. Another signature win came four weeks later when Miami dominated the [[Tennessee Volunteers football|Tennessee Volunteers]], 26â3, before a crowd of 107,745 at [[Neyland Stadium]], considered one of the most hostile road venues in college football. Miami would finish 12â0 and clinch a berth in the [[2003 Fiesta Bowl|Fiesta Bowl]] BCS National Championship Game after a wild 56â45 victory over Virginia Tech in which McGahee rushed for 205 yards and a school-record six touchdowns. Both Dorsey and McGahee were named as finalists for the Heisman Trophy, finishing 4th and 5th, respectively. Miami, in the midst of a 34-game winning streak, was installed as a 13-point favorite in the Fiesta Bowl match up against #2 [[2002 Ohio State Buckeyes football team|Ohio State]]. The Hurricanes took an early 7â0 lead on a 25-yard touchdown pass from Dorsey to [[Roscoe Parrish]], but Ohio State seized control in the second quarter behind an aggressive pass rush, bolstered by constant [[blitz (American football)|blitzing]], and a stifling rush defense. The Buckeyes held a 14â7 lead at the half, and a field goal by [[Mike Nugent]] extended Ohio State's advantage to 17â7 midway through the third quarter. A touchdown run by McGahee brought the Hurricanes within 3 points, but just as the running back started to get on track, he suffered a knee injury early in the fourth quarter.{{cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/sports/football/2009/01/19/2009-01-19_ravens_willis_mcgahee_hospitalized_after.html|title=Ravens' Willis McGahee hospitalized after scary hit in AFC title game|date=2009-01-19|work=[[New York Daily News]]|accessdate=2009-10-17}} Miami was able to fight back and force overtime on a 40-yard field goal by Todd Sievers on the final play of the fourth quarter. Miami scored a touchdown on its first possession in overtime on a 7-yard pass from Dorsey to [[Kellen Winslow II]], and, on Ohio State's ensuing possession, the Hurricanes appeared to have won the game, 24â17, after Buckeyes quarterback [[Craig Krenzel]]'s fourth-and-3 pass from the Miami 5 fell incomplete in the end zone. Miami players and coaches rushed the field and stadium fireworks were set off to commemorate the program's apparent sixth national championship. The celebration proved premature, however, as Big 12 official Terry Porter threw a belated flag and made a controversial [[pass interference]] call against Miami cornerback [[Glenn Sharpe]]. The penalty took the air out of Miami's sails and gave Ohio State new life, first-and-goal at the 1. The Buckeyes scored a touchdown to tie it at 24â24 at the end of the first overtime, and [[Maurice Clarett]]'s 5-yard touchdown run in the second overtime gave Ohio State a 31â24 lead. Miami's ensuing possession saw Dorsey briefly knocked out of the game after a hit from linebacker [[Matt Wilhelm]]. After backup quarterback Derrick Crudup completed an 8-yard pass on third down, Dorsey re-entered and converted the crucial fourth-and-3 with a 7-yard completion to Winslow. Miami then drove to the Ohio State 2 yard-line, but was held to one yard on its next three plays. Facing fourth-and-goal from the Ohio State goal line, Miami called a pass play. The Hurricane offensive line was unable to pick up the blitz and Dorsey's desperation pass into the end zone toward Andre Johnson fell incomplete, giving Ohio State the national championship. The loss was Coker's first in 25 games as Miami's head coach and Dorsey's second in 40 career starts. The loss also continued the Hurricanes' futility in the Fiesta Bowl, dropping them to 0â4 in the game, with two of those losses being monumental upsets that deprived them of national championships. Miami suffered through some offensive struggles in 2003 behind new quarterback [[Brock Berlin]]. A blowout loss at Virginia Tech in early November ended Miami's 39-game regular season winning streak and a loss the following week to [[Tennessee Volunteers football|Tennessee]] ended Miami's national championship aspirations. The Hurricanes rebounded to win the Big East Conference championship and finish the season 11â2 with an [[2004 Orange Bowl]] victory over [[2003 Florida State Seminoles football team|Florida State]]. Miami joined the [[Atlantic Coast Conference|ACC]] in 2004 and despite 3 conference losses, the Hurricanes ended the season with a [[Chick-fil-A Bowl|Peach Bowl]] victory over rival [[2004 Florida Gators football team|Florida]]. The [[2005 Miami Hurricanes football team|2005]] season marked the debut of [[Kyle Wright]] as Miami's starting quarterback, although the much-ballyhooed Wright would struggle with consistency during the season with much of Miami's success that year fueled by its defense. After a loss to Florida State after placekick holder Bryan Monroe bobbled the snap for what would have been a game-tying field goal attempt, Miami would win eight straight games, including a road win over 3rd-ranked Virginia Tech, only to stumble two weeks later against underdog Georgia Tech. Miami's second conference loss of the season cost it a place in the inaugural ACC Championship game and it competed instead in the [[2005 Chick-fil-A Bowl|Peach Bowl]], where it lost to [[2005 LSU Tigers football team|LSU]], 40â3. 2005 also saw the program embroiled in more controversy when it was reported several Miami football players had recorded a rap song in 2004 that contained lewd sexual references.[http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9ujKxpAvLKg Retrieved 2009-10-16.] The song, recorded by an informal group that called itself "7th Floor Crew" and set to the beat of [[Aaliyah]]'s "[[If Your Girl Only Knew]]", received much criticism in outlets such as [[ESPN]] and ''[[Sports Illustrated]]''.{{cite web|url=http://nfl.fanhouse.com/2007/04/30/panthers-bears-draft-7th-floor-crew-members/|title=Panthers, Bears Draft 7th Floor Crew Members â NFL FanHouse|accessdate=2009-10-18}} Following the negative publicity, the University issued a statement condemning its lyrical content.{{cite news|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/espn/page2/story?page=jones/051118/crew|title=Nothing Shocking About 'Crew'|date=2005-11-18|accessdate = 2011-05-21}} The 2006 season included an [[Miami-FIU brawl|on-field brawl]] against [[FIU Golden Panthers football|Florida International]], the shooting death of Miami defensive tackle [[Bryan Pata]], and a four game late-season losing streak. Only a [[Thanksgiving]] night victory over [[2006 Boston College Eagles football team|Boston College]], in Miami's last game of the regular season, saved the Hurricanes from a losing regular season record. The day following the Boston College victory, university president [[Donna Shalala]] terminated Coker.{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2006/11/24/sports/ncaafootball/24cnd-coker.html?scp=8&sq=%22University%20of%20Miami%22&st=cse|title=University of Miami Fires Coach Larry Coker|first=Charlie|last=Nobles|work=New York Times|date=November 24, 2006|accessdate=2010-02-05}} Coker coached through the postseason, where he won his final game, a 21â20 victory over [[Nevada Wolf Pack football|Nevada]] on December 31, 2006 in the [[2006 MPC Computers Bowl|MPC Computers Bowl]]. ===Randy Shannon era (2007â2010)=== [[Image:Randy Shannon 70723.jpg|thumb|[[Randy Shannon]]]] {{Main|2007 Miami Hurricanes football team|2008 Miami Hurricanes football team|2009 Miami Hurricanes football team|2010 Miami Hurricanes football team}} {{See also|2008 Emerald Bowl|2009 Champs Sports Bowl|2010 Sun Bowl}} After a search that lasted two weeks, [[defensive coordinator]] and Miami alumnus [[Randy Shannon]] was officially introduced as the program's new head coach on December 8, 2006. Shannon reportedly agreed to a four-year deal worth over $4 million.{{cite web |url=http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/news/story?id=2690489 |title=Defensive coordinator Shannon new Miami Coach |author=The Associated Press, Mark Schlabach & Joe Schad |publisher=[[ESPN.com]] |date=2006-12-07 |accessdate=2006-12-07 }} As of November 2010, Shannon's .553 career winning record is the worst of any University of Miami coach in four decades. Shannon's first year as UM head coach in 2007 was one of the worst in the Hurricanes' modern history, with the team registering a losing 5â7 record. Shannon was fired by Athletic Director Kirby Hocutt within hours of the loss to USF.{{Citation needed|date=December 2010}} Interim head coach [[Jeff Stoutland]], who was offensive line coach under Shannon, led the team into its Sun Bowl matchup versus [[2010 Notre Dame Fighting Irish football team|Notre Dame]]; the Hurricanes lost the New Year's Eve game 33â17.http://www.hurricanesports.cstv.com/sports/m-footbl/sched/mifl-m-footbl-sched.html#|accessdate=January 10, 2011 ===Al Golden era (2011 to present)=== {{Main|2011 University of Miami athletics scandal|2011 Miami Hurricanes football team}} Following Shannon's firing, Miami hired former [[Temple University]] head coach [[Al Golden (American football)|Al Golden]] as their new head coach on December 13, 2010. From 2000 to 2003, Miami won 34 consecutive games, tying for sixth all-time. The streak started on September 23, 2000 with a 47â10 victory at [[West Virginia Mountaineers football|West Virginia]] and ended on January 3, 2003 with a 31â24 double overtime loss to [[2002 Ohio State Buckeyes football team|Ohio State]] in the [[2003 Fiesta Bowl]]. Miami also won 29 straight games from October 27, 1990 to January 1, 1993, good for thirteenth on the all-time list. That streak was snapped when the top-ranked Hurricanes were upset by second-ranked [[1993 Alabama Crimson Tide football team|Alabama]], 34â13 in the [[1993 Sugar Bowl]]. Miami owns the record for the longest home winning streak in NCAA history, winning 58 straight games at the Orange Bowl. The record streak began with a 38â0 shutout victory over Cincinnati on October 12, 1985 and ended with a 38â20 loss to Washington on September 24, 1994. The 58 game streak includes three Orange Bowl victories where Miami was the away team because of the Orange Bowl's tie to the Big 8 conference.{{cite web | title=NCAA Football Records (see page 213) |url=http://web1.ncaa.org/web_files/stats/football_records/DI/2009/2009Collegiate.pdf|work=NCAA Football records (see page 213)}} In addition to its own lengthy winning streaks, Miami has snapped four streaks of 20 games or more in its history. The only other school to snap four winning streaks of 20 or more games is [[Princeton Tigers football|Princeton]].{{cite web | title=2006 University of Miami Football Media Guide: The History of Hurricanes Football | accessdate=2006-11-11 | url=http://www.cstv.com/auto_pdf/p_hotos/s_chools/mifl/sports/m-footbl/auto_pdf/06-mg-history | format=PDF | work=Hurricanesports.com|publisher=Univ of Miami}} In the [[1984 Orange Bowl]], Miami ended top-ranked [[Nebraska Cornhuskers football|Nebraska]]'s 22-game winning streak and won its first national championship with a 31â30 victory. The Hurricanes halted top-ranked [[Oklahoma Sooners football|Oklahoma]]'s 20-game streak and won their second national championship when they defeated the Sooners, 20â14, in the [[1988 Orange Bowl]]. The Hurricanes ended top-ranked [[1989 Notre Dame Fighting Irish football team|Notre Dame]]'s 23-game winning streak with a 27â10 win on November 25, 1989. Miami also had heated rivalry with [[Notre Dame Fighting Irish football|Notre Dame]] through 1990.{{cite web|url=http://nbcsports.msnbc.com/id/30355617|title=Notre DameâMiami rivalry to be renewed?|date=2009-04-22|work=NBCSports.com|accessdate=2009-10-15}} ===Florida State=== {{See also|MiamiâFlorida State football rivalry|Wide Right I|Wide Right II}} The Miami-Florida State rivalry dates to 1951, when the Hurricanes defeated the Seminoles 35â13 in their inaugural meeting. The schools have played every year since 1966, with Miami holding the all-time advantage, 31â25. Upon the conclusion of their 2003 regular-season schedules, the teams represented their respective conferences in the 2004 [[FedEx Orange Bowl]] (Miami being the champions of the Big East, and Florida State being the champions of the ACC). Miami won the bowl game 16â14, it was the only time the schools have met in post-season football play. Following their October 2010 contest, the 55 meetings between the teams of FSU and Miami eclipses a rivalry between the Hurricanes and the Gators (from the [[University of Florida]]); the series of games between UM and Florida becomes Miami's second-longest at 54 games. During the 1980s and '90s, the series emerged as one of the premier rivalries in college football.{{Citation needed|date=October 2009}} Between 1983 and 2002, the Hurricanes and Seminoles combined to win 7 national championships and play in 14 bowl games with a national championship at stake. The 1988 game starred 57 future [[NFL]] pros on the combined rosters. Since 2004, the year Miami left the [[Big East Conference]] to join the expanded 12-member [[Atlantic Coast Conference]], the universities have been conference foes, though they are placed in separate divisions consisting of six institutions. This alignment brings about the potential of the two teams meeting for a second time, should each win their respective divisions in any particular season, at the [[ACC Championship Game]]. Played annually since 2005, the victor of the early December contest becomes the ACC champion, and subsequently the Conference's representative in the [[Bowl Championship Series]] (BCS) that year. Under the current arrangement with the BCS, the intent has been to send the ACC champion to the [[FedEx Orange Bowl]] in Miami each year, although provisions exist that permit teams to be placed in one of the other four BCS bowls, dependent upon the rankings of the teams and the location of that season's BCS Championship Game. The series has consistently drawn very high [[Nielsen ratings|television ratings]] with the 2006 Miami â Florida State game being the most-watched college football gameâregular-season or postseasonâin [[ESPN]] history, and the 2009 and 1994 meetings being the second- and fifth-most watched regular season games, respectively.{{cite news|url=http://www.miamiherald.com/news/breaking-news/story/1226762.html|title=ESPN viewers flocked to Miami HurricanesâFSU matchup|last=Miller Degnan|first=Susan|date=2009-09-10|work=[[The Miami Herald]]|accessdate=2009-09-12}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}} ===Florida=== {{Main|War Canoe Trophy}} Miami's rivalry with [[Florida Gators football|Florida]] dates back to 1938, making it the oldest rivalry among Florida's "Big Three" of Miami, Florida, and Florida State. The Hurricanes defeated the Gators, 19â7, in the first meeting between the geographic rivals. The Seminole War Canoe was carved in 1950 out of a cypress struck by lightning and was given to the winner of the annual football game. The canoe is meant to symbolize the fighting spirit of the Seminole people that is often on display during games between the Hurricanes and Gators. The canoe is now on permanent display at the University of Miami Sports Hall of Fame on the Coral Gables campus. Miami holds the edge in the all-time series with a 28â26 record against Florida. The two schools met every year from 1944 until 1987, but have not played regularly since then. Florida canceled the annual series after the 1987 season, when the requirement of the [[Southeastern Conference]] for member schools to play eight conference games induced the University of Florida to fill out the non-conference portion of its schedule with teams that do not require a home-and-home arrangement. From 1986 to 2003, Miami won all six of the games between the schools, including victories in the 2001 [[Sugar Bowl]] and the 2004 [[Peach Bowl]]. Florida snapped its 23-year drought against Miami with a 26â3 win over the Hurricanes in 2008. The two schools are next scheduled to play in 2013 at [[Sun Life Stadium]].{{cite web|url=http://www.nationalchamps.net/NCAA/future_schedules/miamiFL_future.htm |title=Miami Hurricanes Football Future Schedules |publisher=NationalChamps.net |accessdate=2009-11-20}} ===Notre Dame=== {{Main|Catholics vs. Convicts}} While not the most regular rivalry for either school, Notre Dame's games with Miami, dubbed by Irish fans in the late 1980s as "Catholics vs. Convicts" still stand out as one of the most heated feuds in college football history. After not meeting for two decades, the schools faced each other in the 2010 Sun Bowl, with Notre Dame prevailing 33â17.
